Let's gather the things we need.
Some things we need for this craft are:
The tissue box is going to be the body of our guitar.
The hole in the box is a lot like the holes that we see
The cardboard tube is going to be the neck of our guitar,
and you can paint them both any color you like.
I painted my tissue box my favorite color, blue,
it's dry and all ready to go.
We'll attach our cardboard tube by tracing the end of it
onto one side of the cardboard box.
Then a grownup can help you carefully cut that out
And we're gonna put the cardboard tube inside.
And it doesn't have to be perfect
because once the cardboard tube goes in,
if it's a little bit smaller,
it'll stay nice and snug in place, there.
Now our guitar is ready for our strings.
We're gonna use elastic bands, I have some orange ones here.
We're gonna add four elastic bands,
two on the top of the cardboard tube and two on the bottom.
My guitar in the classroom has six strings,
but this is a crafty guitar, so it has four.
Different elastic bands will make different sounds.
You might like to experiment using thin ones
or thicker ones, smaller ones or bigger ones
and see what sound you like for your guitar.
To make our guitar sound a little bit better,
we're gonna add in some popsicle sticks.
We can glue two regular popsicle sticks
on top of each other just to make it a little bit thicker,
And we'll carefully stick them underneath the elastic bands
and just push them to one side.
I have another one here, push it to the other side,
and that'll help make it sound a little bit better.
Now our guitar is all ready to decorate.
You can decorate yours any way you like,
maybe with some stickers, maybe a smiley face sticker.
And once it's all decorated, it might look like this.
I added in some pom poms for the knobs on the neck,
lots of different stickers and jewels,
and even some double-sided tape on the neck of the guitar,
just wrapped it around so it looks like a real guitar neck.
